question.title: Will Ukraine achieve full operational interoperability with NATO forces by 2027?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, Ukraine has achieved full operational interoperability with NATO forces as defined by the NATO standards for interoperability, which includes successful joint exercises, integration of command and control systems, and the ability to operate seamlessly with NATO forces in a combined mission. This must be confirmed by official NATO reports or statements from NATO leadership. Additionally, the interoperability must be demonstrated in at least one multinational operation involving NATO member states. The resolution will also consider any credible assessments from defense analysts or reputable defense publications (e.g., Defense News, Jane's Defence) regarding Ukraine's interoperability status with NATO.

question.title: Given Ukraine achieves full operational interoperability with NATO forces by 2027, will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

Resolution criteria for the condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, Ukraine has achieved full operational interoperability with NATO forces as defined by the NATO standards for interoperability, which includes successful joint exercises, integration of command and control systems, and the ability to operate seamlessly with NATO forces in a combined mission. This must be confirmed by official NATO reports or statements from NATO leadership. Additionally, the interoperability must be demonstrated in at least one multinational operation involving NATO member states. The resolution will also consider any credible assessments from defense analysts or reputable defense publications (e.g., Defense News, Jane's Defence) regarding Ukraine's interoperability status with NATO.

question.title: Given Ukraine achieves full operational interoperability with NATO forces by 2027 and joins NATO before 2030, will NATO expand its presence in Eastern Europe in response to Ukraine's potential membership by 2029?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if BOTH of the following occur: (1) By December 31, 2027, Ukraine has achieved full operational interoperability with NATO forces as defined by NATO standards for interoperability, which includes successful joint exercises, integration of command and control systems, and the ability to operate seamlessly with NATO forces in a combined mission. This must be confirmed by official NATO reports or statements from NATO leadership. Additionally, the interoperability must be demonstrated in at least one multinational operation involving NATO member states. The resolution will also consider any credible assessments from defense analysts or reputable defense publications (e.g., Defense News, Jane's Defence) regarding Ukraine's interoperability status with NATO. (2) Before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2029, NATO has officially expanded its military presence in Eastern Europe as a direct response to Ukraine's potential membership in NATO. This includes any increase in troop deployments, establishment of new bases, or significant military exercises conducted in Eastern European NATO member countries specifically citing Ukraine's membership as a reason for the expansion. The decision must be confirmed through official NATO communications or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Any temporary deployments or exercises not explicitly linked to Ukraine's membership will not count towards this resolution.

question.title: Conditional on NATO expanding its presence in Eastern Europe in response to Ukraine's potential membership by 2029, will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before being accepted into NATO?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Ukraine and Russia reach a formal agreement that resolves all territorial disputes, which must be recognized by both parties and include specific terms regarding the status of disputed territories. The agreement must be publicly announced and confirmed by credible sources, including at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The resolution will also consider any agreements that are part of the NATO accession process, specifically if they lead to a clear and lasting resolution of territorial disputes. Temporary ceasefires or informal agreements will not count towards resolution.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2029, NATO has officially expanded its military presence in Eastern Europe as a direct response to Ukraine's potential membership in NATO. This includes any increase in troop deployments, establishment of new bases, or significant military exercises conducted in Eastern European NATO member countries specifically citing Ukraine's membership as a reason for the expansion. The decision must be confirmed through official NATO communications or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Any temporary deployments or exercises not explicitly linked to Ukraine's membership will not count towards this resolution.

If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

question.title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

metadata.source_question: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?

question.title: Conditional on a new infectious disease prompting the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030, will significant advancements in vaccine technology occur as a result of a new infectious disease outbreak by 2030?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

This question will then resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any of the following significant advancements in vaccine technology are recognized and documented as a direct result of the new infectious disease outbreak:

1. Development of a new vaccine platform that demonstrates efficacy in clinical trials against the outbreak disease.
2. Significant improvements in vaccine production methods that reduce time to market for a vaccine in response to the outbreak, as recognized by regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA.
3. Successful implementation of a novel delivery method for vaccines that is adopted in response to the outbreak and shows improved efficacy or accessibility.

Advancements must be reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and must be acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC. The advancements must not be incremental improvements but rather substantial innovations directly linked to the outbreak.

question.title: Conditional on both the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies and significant advancements in vaccine technology due to a new infectious disease outbreak by 2030, will governments increase funding for pandemic preparedness measures due to a new infectious disease by 2027?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, any government (federal, state, or local) in a recognized country increases its budgetary allocation for pandemic preparedness measures in response to the emergence of a new infectious disease. The increase must be publicly documented and reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) or through official government announcements. The new infectious disease must be classified as a significant threat by the World Health Organization (WHO) or equivalent health authority, leading to a measurable increase in funding compared to the year prior. Temporary or one-time funding increases for specific events or emergencies that do not lead to sustained funding changes will not count towards this resolution.

This is conditional on both of the following occurring by December 31, 2030:
1. A new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. The development must be officially recognized and reported by reputable sources such as the WHO, CDC, or a major news organization. The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease.
2. Significant advancements in vaccine technology are recognized and documented as a direct result of a new infectious disease outbreak. These advancements must be substantial innovations directly linked to the outbreak and reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets, and acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies and significant advancements in vaccine technology by 2030, and (2) governments increase funding for pandemic preparedness measures due to a new infectious disease by 2027?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:

1. By December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies and significant advancements in vaccine technology. The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies. Significant advancements in vaccine technology must be recognized and documented as a direct result of a new infectious disease outbreak. Any of the following significant advancements in vaccine technology must occur:
    a. Development of a new vaccine platform that demonstrates efficacy in clinical trials against the outbreak disease.
    b. Significant improvements in vaccine production methods that reduce time to market for a vaccine in response to the outbreak, as recognized by regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA.
    c. Successful implementation of a novel delivery method for vaccines that is adopted in response to the outbreak and shows improved efficacy or accessibility. Advancements must be reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and must be acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC. The advancements must not be incremental improvements but rather substantial innovations directly linked to the outbreak.

2. By December 31, 2027, any government (federal, state, or local) in a recognized country increases its budgetary allocation for pandemic preparedness measures in response to the emergence of a new infectious disease. The increase must be publicly documented and reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) or through official government announcements. The new infectious disease must be classified as a significant threat by the World Health Organization (WHO) or equivalent health authority, leading to a measurable increase in funding compared to the year prior. Temporary or one-time funding increases for specific events or emergencies that do not lead to sustained funding changes will not count towards this resolution.

The increase must be publicly documented and reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) or through official government announcements. The new infectious disease must be classified as a significant threat by the World Health Organization (WHO) or equivalent health authority, leading to a measurable increase in funding compared to the year prior. Temporary or one-time funding increases for specific events or emergencies that do not lead to sustained funding changes will not count towards this resolution.

Then is the following true: By December 31, 2028, an infectious disease emerges that leads to the establishment of internationally recognized biocontainment protocols. The following conditions must be met for the protocols to be considered established: 1. The protocols must be formally adopted by at least three major international health organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). 2. The protocols must be implemented in response to the disease, addressing containment measures, travel restrictions, and public health guidelines. 3. The disease must be classified as a significant threat to global health, as determined by the aforementioned organizations. 4. The establishment of protocols must be publicly announced and documented in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If multiple diseases emerge, the resolution will be based on the first disease that meets these criteria.

question.body:

Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. 1. The protocols must be formally adopted by at least three major international health organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). 
2. The protocols must be implemented in response to the disease, addressing containment measures, travel restrictions, and public health guidelines.

4. The establishment of protocols must be publicly announced and documented in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If multiple diseases emerge, the resolution will be based on the first disease that meets these criteria.

question.title: Conditional on both the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies by 2030 and the establishment of international biocontainment protocols by 2028 due to new infectious diseases, will a new infectious disease outbreak prompt the establishment of a dedicated international agency for infectious disease response by 2032?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: 

(a) By December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. (b) By December 31, 2028, an infectious disease emerges that leads to the establishment of internationally recognized biocontainment protocols. The following conditions must be met for the protocols to be considered established: 1. The protocols must be formally adopted by at least three major international health organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). 2. The protocols must be implemented in response to the disease, addressing containment measures, travel restrictions, and public health guidelines. 3. The disease must be classified as a significant threat to global health, as determined by the aforementioned organizations. 4. The establishment of protocols must be publicly announced and documented in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If multiple diseases emerge, the resolution will be based on the first disease that meets these criteria.

Then, will a new infectious disease outbreak prompt the establishment of a dedicated international agency for infectious disease response by 2032? The outbreak must be recognized by the World Health Organization (WHO) and result in a formal announcement by at least two major countries or international bodies regarding the need for such an agency. The agency must be operational and have a defined mandate that includes coordination of international responses to infectious disease threats. The resolution will not count temporary task forces or committees but must involve a permanent agency with sustained funding and authority.

question.title: Will a new infectious disease result in the creation of a global health surveillance system by 2035?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, a global health surveillance system is officially established in response to a new infectious disease that meets the following criteria: 
- The system must be designed to monitor, report, and respond to infectious disease outbreaks on a global scale, with participation from multiple countries and international health organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO).
- The surveillance system must include real-time data collection, analysis, and sharing mechanisms that allow for rapid identification and response to infectious disease threats.
- The creation of this system must be documented by official reports, declarations, or agreements from recognized global health authorities, such as the WHO, and must be operational, not merely proposed or in a planning stage.
- In the event of a partial implementation, the question will resolve as Yes if the system is intended for global application and not limited to specific regions or countries. Temporary or ad-hoc systems for specific outbreaks do not count towards this resolution.

question.title: Conditional on both the creation of a global health surveillance system and the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies due to a new infectious disease, will significant advancements in vaccine technology occur as a result of the same new infectious disease outbreak by 2030?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any of the following significant advancements in vaccine technology are recognized and documented as a direct result of a new infectious disease outbreak:

1. Development of a new vaccine platform that demonstrates efficacy in clinical trials against the outbreak disease.
2. Significant improvements in vaccine production methods that reduce time to market for a vaccine in response to the outbreak, as recognized by regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA.
3. Successful implementation of a novel delivery method for vaccines that is adopted in response to the outbreak and shows improved efficacy or accessibility.

Advancements must be reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and must be acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC. question.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?

The event must be recognized by the international sporting community and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or unofficial events, such as friendly matches or local competitions, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then is the following true: By December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled or held in a country recognized by credible human rights organizations (such as Amnesty International or Human Rights Watch) as having a controversial human rights record. A controversial human rights record is defined as a country that has been reported to have significant issues such as political repression, lack of freedom of speech, arbitrary detentions, or discrimination against marginalized groups. The confirmation must come from an official Formula 1 announcement or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the race is held in a country that is later determined to have a controversial human rights record based on reports released after the event, the question will resolve as No.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by 2025: (1) A Formula 1 Grand Prix and any international sporting event be hosted in countries currently under international sanctions, and (2) A Formula 1 Grand Prix be held in a country with a controversial human rights record?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur by December 31, 2025: (1) A Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled and held in a country that is currently under international sanctions recognized by at least one major international body (such as the United Nations or the European Union). The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the event must be confirmed by the official Formula 1 calendar or an official announcement from the Formula 1 organization. Temporary events or exhibitions do not count, and the Grand Prix must be part of the regular Formula 1 season. If the country is removed from sanctions before the event, the resolution will be No. Additionally, an international sporting event (such as the Olympics, World Cup, or any major international tournament) must be officially hosted in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or other recognized international bodies. The sanctions must be in effect at the time the event is announced and during its hosting. The event must be recognized by the international sporting community and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or unofficial events, such as friendly matches or local competitions, do not count towards this question's resolution. (2) A Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled or held in a country recognized by credible human rights organizations (such as Amnesty International or Human Rights Watch) as having a controversial human rights record. A controversial human rights record is defined as a country that has been reported to have significant issues such as political repression, lack of freedom of speech, arbitrary detentions, or discrimination against marginalized groups. The confirmation must come from an official Formula 1 announcement or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the race is held in a country that is later determined to have a controversial human rights record based on reports released after the event, the question will resolve as No.
